Situation1: This is the last weekend before the partner relocates abroad for months.
Expectation2: Communicate politely and professionally with customers
Situation2: The customer asks about the delivery status, while a delivery issue arises, such as a delayed or misplaced package
Story: I had been looking forward to this weekend for weeks. It was the last one before my boyfriend left for his new job overseas, and we’d promised to make every moment count. We were curled up on the couch, his head on my shoulder, when my phone buzzed. I glanced at the screen—another message from a customer. My heart sank. There was a problem with their package, and they wanted an update right away. I could feel my boyfriend’s eyes on me, waiting for me to put the phone away and focus on us. But as a delivery person, I was expected to respond quickly, to be calm and professional, even when things went wrong. My fingers hovered over the keyboard, torn between sending a reassuring message to the customer and tossing my phone aside to savor these precious hours. The weight of both roles pressed down on me, each demanding something I wasn’t sure I could give at the same time.
